data.question: What is the yield percentage of the guest-embedded network 1•3 when synthesized using a methanol solution of ZnI2 layered onto a nitrobenzene/methanol solution of 2 and diene 3?
What method was used to confirm the enclathration of dienophiles 4a–c in the pores of the inclusion complexes 1•3•4a–c?
What was the conversion percentage and regioselectivity ratio for the Diels–Alder reaction between diene 3 and 2-methyl N-methylmaleimide (4c) within network 1?
Does the crystalline molecular flask network 1 enhance the reactivity of Diels–Alder reactions compared to solution reactions?
Is the yield of the Diels–Alder adduct 5a higher in the crystalline state reaction within network 1 compared to the control experiment in solution?
Was the Diels–Alder reaction between diene 3 and 2-methoxy N-methylmaleimide (4b) successful under neat conditions?
What is the role of cyclohexane in the preparation of inclusion complexes 1•3•4a–c?
data.answer: Cyclohexane was used to replace nitrobenzene in the pores of as-synthesized 1•3 before introducing dienophiles 4a–c.

data.question: How does the presence of ZnI2 and triazine ligand 2 affect the Diels–Alder reaction between diene 3 and 2-methoxy N-methylmaleimide (4b) in solution?
data.answer: The presence of ZnI2 and triazine ligand 2 does not result in the formation of the Diels–Alder adduct 5b in solution.

data.question: What is the significance of the microscopic FT-IR spectra in the analysis of the Diels–Alder reactions within network 1?
data.answer: The microscopic FT-IR spectra confirm the enclathration of dienophiles in the pores and the formation of Diels–Alder adducts by showing new bands attributable to the carbonyl stretching vibration.

data.question: Can the crystalline molecular flask network 1 selectively control the regioselectivity of Diels–Alder reactions?
Is the yield of Diels–Alder adduct 5b from the reaction between diene 3 and 2-methoxy N-methylmaleimide (4b) within network 1 higher than the yield of the control experiment in solution?
What is the effect of the crystalline molecular flask network 1 on the stereochemistry of the Diels–Alder adducts?
data.answer: The crystalline molecular flask network 1 allows for regio- and stereocontrolled transformations with high conversion.

data.question: Does the crystalline molecular flask network 1 require the use of additional catalysts for the Diels–Alder reactions?
What is the role of π–π interactions in the positioning of the Diels–Alder diene reactant within network 1?
data.answer: The π–π interactions with ligand 2 geometrically fix the Diels–Alder diene reactant in an ideal position for the reaction.

data.question: How does the crystalline molecular flask network 1 compare to common porous networks in terms of guest uptake?
data.answer: Unlike common porous networks that rely on diffusion-driven guest uptake, network 1 captures guests through specific host–guest interactions.

data.question: Is the crystalline molecular flask network 1 capable of achieving high conversion rates for Diels–Alder reactions without guest disorder?
What is the significance of the electrostatic potential surfaces in understanding the molecular recognition within network 1?
data.answer: The electrostatic potential surfaces provide a qualitative understanding of the attractive interactions between the electron-rich and electron-deficient areas of the reactants, facilitating molecular recognition.

data.question: Does the crystalline molecular flask network 1 allow for in situ X-ray observation of Diels–Alder reactions?
What is the role of hydrogen bonds in the recognition of dienophiles within network 1?
data.answer: Hydrogen bonds between the carbonyl oxygen of the dienophiles and the Py-Hβ proton of ligand 2 facilitate the recognition and positioning of the dienophiles for the Diels–Alder reaction.

data.question: Is the crystalline molecular flask network 1 effective in controlling the regioselectivity of Diels–Alder reactions for different dienophiles?
